title: Creating Particle Factories
description: Learn how to enhance particles with custom particle factories.

children.value: Custom particle factories allow for the already powerful particles to become super powerful. You can add small rotating leaves to a beautiful scene, or huge, powerful explosions to an intense boss battle. Let's learn about them and make one!

You can think of a particle factory as the particle's code. In this example, we are going to make our smiley faced texture from the Creating Custom Particles tutorial fall slowly, spin, and change size, then stop all movement and fade away upon hitting the ground.

To use a custom particle factory, you'll need to create a class to contain all of the code. If you plan on making multiple factories, or just want to keep your packages organized, then you will probably want to create a new package called
(this package would be placed in the same package as your "ClientModInitializer" class). This package will contain all of your particle factories.
Next up, create a new class with the name of your particle. For this example, we will be calling it
. We have a particle already named "myparticle", however, if you had a particle named "fireball", you could name the class "FireballParticle.class".
Your particle needs code! A lot of code. Let's begin by having our class extend the
class. You will also need to have the
You then will need to create the methods required for the particle to function.
//Leave at least one line of space here for later
//Activated once as soon as the particle spawns
//Activated every single tick the particle is alive
//Allows for the particle to determine its texture "type" to a degree
Depending on your IDE of choice, the ParticleTextureSheet may have automatically been added and returned a value of "null". If that is the case, then let it be for now.
The code above is for some of the methods required to make your particle have motion. There are still more methods to come, however. But first, let's add some code to the stuff we already have.
In the particle's constructor, there are many variables you can choose to edit to your liking. Here is a list of some of the most common variables you may want to edit.
: Typically the amount of ticks the particle has been in the world.
: Typically the total amount of ticks the particle has in the world.
: The opacity, or transparency, of the particle.
: A boolean which determines if the particle should collide with the world or not.
The following are typically determined by the method caller.
: The velocity of the particle in the "x" coordinate direction.
: The velocity of the particle in the "y" coordinate direction.
: The velocity of the particle in the "z" coordinate direction.
Once you have figured out which variables you want to adjust, and which ones you want to leave as default, it is time to continue adding code!

Back to your particle's constructor, it is finally time to add some code! At this point, you should have some variables in mind for what you want to add. However, if there is a variable you missed, you can always come back and add them!

As mentioned earlier, our goal is to make a particle which falls slowly, spins, and changes size, then stop all movement and fade away upon hitting the ground. This means we're going to want to have some variables to allow for this, like the
There are also variables we'd just want in general, like the
, as well as the variables related to positioning.
//The sprite provider which is used to determine the particle's texture
//Sets the sprite provider from above to the sprite provider in the constructor parameters
//Setting the alpha to 1.0f means there will be no opacity change until the alpha value is changed
Now, that's a lot of code! Let's go over it a little bit more. Firstly, we need to make sure to set the
), to ensure the particle spawns at the right position.
variable? Why did we set that to a predetermined number? Well, our goal is to make it so that our particle falls at the same rate every time. Setting the
variable ahead of time helps reduce repeated code. However, if you think you may want to change the
variable depending on when you call it, then it wouldn't be a bad idea to change the variable to be determined by the constructor's parameter.
Adding Code to The Tick Method
There are a lot of ways you could go about doing the code for the tick method. In this example, we will be making it where our
variable is the amount of ticks the particle has been in the world, and our
variable is the total amount of ticks the particle should be in the world before despawning. This is how most Minecraft particles work.
//Despawns the particle if the age has reached the max age, or if the scale is 0
We have started by adding what is required. A way to despawn the particle, a way to move the particle, and a way to animate the particle. You can comment out the
line to remove animation from the particle, and instead have the particle choose one of the textures!
Next, let's add some life to our particle!
//Despawns the particle if the age has reached the max age, or if the scale is 0, or if the alpha is 0
//If the particle isn't on the ground
//Slowly fades away upon hitting the ground
Woah, what's going on here? A lot of simple checks, actually! Let's break down the code.
First, we are detecting if the particle is off the ground with the
on the ground, it will continue the statement. The statement continues by slightly changing the particle's angle. Then it asks if the particle has progressed through a third of its age with the
code. If so, then it starts to shrink the particle. Otherwise, it'll continue to grow the particle.
on the ground? If the particle is on the ground, the particle losses

velocity. It still has the velocityY, because we never set it to 0. We don't need to. The reason why we set it to something in the first place is to let it hit the ground. And now that it is on the ground, and because the particle collides with the world, the particle stops the "y" velocity automatically!
We also begin to reduce the particle's alpha, until it eventually despawns whenever the alpha hits 0, thanks to the
We are getting very close to completing our beautiful new particle factory. But, we need to figure out which TextureSheet is best for us. Let's go with
, as it allows for our particle to have some transparency. An alternative is
, which does not allow for any transparency.
//Allows for the texture to have some transparency

There is one last method we need to add before testing our particle. It is the method which will be called whenever registering a particle with our factory. Add the following code to the bottom of your particle class.
//The factory used in a particle's registry
(clientWorld, x, y, z, velX, velY, velZ,
Once you are done adding that, your particle code is complete!
Don't load up your game yet, as you still need to register your particle using this new particle factory.
class, edit your particle register to include our new particle factory.
Now that your particle factory is being used in the particle registry, you can load up your game and test out the particle!
The Most Beautiful Particle You Will Ever See
Try spawning the particle a block in the air, 5 blocks in the air, and 10 whole blocks in the air!
A single block in the air and 5 blocks in the air.
//The sprite provider which is used to determine the particle's texture
//Sets the sprite provider from above to the sprite provider in the constructor method
//Setting the alpha to 1.0f means there will be no opacity change until the alpha value is changed
//Despawns the particle if the age has reached the max age, or if the scale is 0, or if the alpha is 0
//If the particle isn't on the ground
//Slowly fades away upon hitting the ground
//Allows for the texture to have some transparency
//The factory used in a particle's registry
(clientWorld, x, y, z, velX, velY, velZ,
